elements.content: A solvent responsive, dynamic, three-dimensional supramolecular porous host has been synthesized and structurally characterized. The structural flexibility is realized by the guest responsive structural transformation and also by the different gas and solvent vapor adsorption studies. Noncovalent encapsulation of fluorescein dye into the framework resulted in dual emission through host-to-guest partial energy transfer which is utilized for solvent sensing. Diffusion of solvents modulates the structural arrangement and energy transfer.
elements.clean_text: A solvent responsive, dynamic, three-dimensional supramolecular porous host has been synthesized and structurally characterized. The structural flexibility is realized by the guest responsive structural transformation and also by the different gas and solvent vapor adsorption studies. Noncovalent encapsulation of fluorescein dye into the framework resulted in dual emission through host-to-guest partial energy transfer which is utilized for solvent sensing. Diffusion of solvents modulates the structural arrangement and energy transfer.

elements.content: A flexible, supramolecular porous framework based on a mixed linker system has been synthesized and characterized that exhibits solvent modulated host-to-guest energy transfer toward fingerprint sensing.
elements.clean_text: A flexible, supramolecular porous framework based on a mixed linker system has been synthesized and characterized that exhibits solvent modulated host-to-guest energy transfer toward fingerprint sensing.

elements.content:
Published as part of the Crystal Growth and Design Israel Goldberg Memorial virtual special issue

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are well-known for their high crystallinity, structural modularity, and versatile functionalities. On the basis of these features, PCPs show potential applications in gas storage and separation, catalysis, drug delivery, magnetism, etc. The luminescent PCPs are also very promising for molecular sensing, light harvesting, and nonlinear optical properties. Molecular recognition or sensing of metal ions, anions, volatile solvents using PCPs have been reported quite often, and all of those are mostly dependent on luminescence intensity from single transition (or one excited state). An easy visual readout sensing material must show a prominent shift of the emission spectra (color), or a switch on/off feature. Subtle changes in emission intensity in the presence of the analyte may not strongly establish sensing efficacy. Instead, a dual emissive porous material can be much more effective to fabricate an easy readout sensory material. To date, using PCPs in such efforts has been scarce.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of the Crystal Growth and Design Israel Goldberg Memorial virtual special issue 

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are well-known for their high crystallinity, structural modularity, and versatile functionalities. On the basis of these features, PCPs show potential applications in gas storage and separation, catalysis, drug delivery, magnetism, etc. The luminescent PCPs are also very promising for molecular sensing, light harvesting, and nonlinear optical properties. Molecular recognition or sensing of metal ions, anions, volatile solvents using PCPs have been reported quite often, and all of those are mostly dependent on luminescence intensity from single transition (or one excited state). An easy visual readout sensing material must show a prominent shift of the emission spectra (color), or a switch on/off feature. Subtle changes in emission intensity in the presence of the analyte may not strongly establish sensing efficacy. Instead, a dual emissive porous material can be much more effective to fabricate an easy readout sensory material. To date, using PCPs in such efforts has been scarce.

elements.content: To synthesize a dual emissive material, the use of host–guest chemistry is most suitable. The requirements are a luminescent PCP with substantial porosity and an emissive dye molecule that can fit into the pores of the host PCP. Additionally, a partial energy transfer between the host and the encapsulated dye may lead to a dual emissive material. A very efficient energy transfer could lead to an enhanced emission of the acceptor dye only and will result into a single emission peak. Considering these aforementioned conditions, we envisioned that a PCP@dye dual emissive material, which has substantial void space even after filling the pores by guest dye molecules, can be a promising sensory material. Filling out the remaining void space by the analyte can (i) bring a solvatochromic shift to the both/single emission peak, or (ii) modulate the host-to-guest energy transfer process and change the emission intensity ratio. In this process, even a small change in one of the emission peak intensities can render a significant emission color change in the presence of a selective analyte. In this regard, flexible luminescent PCPs with an adaptable pore structure can be ideal hosts as these can accommodate multiple guest molecules via structural modification stabilized by host–guest interactions. Adopting one of our previously established strategies, a luminescent three-dimensional (3D) porous supramolecular framework based on one-dimensional (1D) coordination chain {[Zn­(ndc)­(2,2′-bpy)]­·2DMF)} n (1) (ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate; 2,2′-bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine, DMF = dimethylformamide) has been synthesized as a host structure. 1 exhibited substantial structural flexibility, and encapsulation of a fluorescein (fl) dye into the supramolecular pores furnished a dual emission feature (yellow-green) (). The presence of void space even after dye encapsulation allowed further diffusion of various solvents, resulting in a tuned emission color due to structural change as well as modulation of a host-to-guest energy transfer process.
elements.clean_text: To synthesize a dual emissive material, the use of host-guest chemistry is most suitable. The requirements are a luminescent PCP with substantial porosity and an emissive dye molecule that can fit into the pores of the host PCP. Additionally, a partial energy transfer between the host and the encapsulated dye may lead to a dual emissive material. A very efficient energy transfer could lead to an enhanced emission of the acceptor dye only and will result into a single emission peak. Considering these aforementioned conditions, we envisioned that a PCP@dye dual emissive material, which has substantial void space even after filling the pores by guest dye molecules, can be a promising sensory material. Filling out the remaining void space by the analyte can (i) bring a solvatochromic shift to the both/single emission peak, or (ii) modulate the host-to-guest energy transfer process and change the emission intensity ratio. In this process, even a small change in one of the emission peak intensities can render a significant emission color change in the presence of a selective analyte. In this regard, flexible luminescent PCPs with an adaptable pore structure can be ideal hosts as these can accommodate multiple guest molecules via structural modification stabilized by host-guest interactions. Adopting one of our previously established strategies, a luminescent three-dimensional (3D) porous supramolecular framework based on one-dimensional (1D) coordination chain {[Zn(ndc)(2,2'-bpy)]⋅2DMF)} n  (1) (ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate; 2,2'-bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine, DMF = dimethylformamide) has been synthesized as a host structure. 1 exhibited substantial structural flexibility, and encapsulation of a fluorescein (fl) dye into the supramolecular pores furnished a dual emission feature (yellow-green) (). The presence of void space even after dye encapsulation allowed further diffusion of various solvents, resulting in a tuned emission color due to structural change as well as modulation of a host-to-guest energy transfer process.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>A Supramolecular
Luminescent, Porous Framework with an Encapsulated
Dye Showing Host-to-Guest Energy Transfer and Guest Solvent Responsive
Emission for Fingerprint Sensing</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr5" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2018-018406_0005.tif" xlink:type="simple"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 1  A Supramolecular Luminescent, Porous Framework with an Encapsulated Dye Showing Host-to-Guest Energy Transfer and Guest Solvent Responsive Emission for Fingerprint Sensing

elements.content: A solvothermal reaction of Zn­(II), ndc, and 2,2′-bpy produces colorless rod-shaped crystals of 1. Structure determination using single crystal X-ray diffraction suggests that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit contains one Zn­(II) metal center, one ndc, one 2,2′-bpy, and two guest DMF molecules. The hexacoordinated Zn­(II) metal center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O1A, O2A, O1A_a, and O2A_a) from two carboxylate groups of ndc and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N1_a) from one 2,2′-bpy. The ndc linkers connect two metal centers in bidentate mode, and 2,2′-bpy binds in a chelating fashion to form a 1D zigzag chain (a). These 1D chains are held together on the ac plane through hydrogen bonding interactions between C6A–H···O2 to form an undulated 2D structure. These 2D layers stack along the c-axis through a face-to-face π···π interaction (∼3.518 Å) between 2,2′-bpy moieties of neighboring 1D chains (b) that affords a 3D supramolecular framework furnishing large dumbell-shaped 1D channels with dimensions 14.5 × 9 Å2 (c). These channels are filled with guest DMF molecules, confirmed from thermogravimetric (TG) analysis and elemental analysis. Calculated void space after removal of guest DMF molecules using PLATON software is 44% of the total cell volume.
elements.clean_text: A solvothermal reaction of Zn(II), ndc, and 2,2'-bpy produces colorless rod-shaped crystals of 1. Structure determination using single crystal X-ray diffraction suggests that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) metal center, one ndc, one 2,2'-bpy, and two guest DMF molecules. The hexacoordinated Zn(II) metal center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms (O1A, O2A, O1A_a, and O2A_a) from two carboxylate groups of ndc and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N1_a) from one 2,2'-bpy. The ndc linkers connect two metal centers in bidentate mode, and 2,2'-bpy binds in a chelating fashion to form a 1D zigzag chain (a). These 1D chains are held together on the ac plane through hydrogen bonding interactions between C6A-H⋅⋅⋅O2 to form an undulated 2D structure. These 2D layers stack along the c-axis through a face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interaction (~3.518 Å) between 2,2'-bpy moieties of neighboring 1D chains (b) that affords a 3D supramolecular framework furnishing large dumbell-shaped 1D channels with dimensions 14.5 × 9 Å2 (c). These channels are filled with guest DMF molecules, confirmed from thermogravimetric (TG) analysis and elemental analysis. Calculated void space after removal of guest DMF molecules using PLATON software is 44% of the total cell volume.

elements.content: (a) 1D structure formed by connecting Zn­(II) and ndc; (b) π–π stacking of the 2,2′-bpy from neighboring 2D sheets along the c-axis; (c) van der Waals surface added view of the dumbell-shaped 1D channels along the c-axis.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) 1D structure formed by connecting Zn(II) and ndc; (b) π-π stacking of the 2,2'-bpy from neighboring 2D sheets along the c-axis; (c) van der Waals surface added view of the dumbell-shaped 1D channels along the c-axis.

elements.content: To assess the potential of 1 as a suitable host, we have examined its porosity and structural flexibility. The TG analysis of 1 showed release of the guest DMF molecules at 170 °C, and the desolvated state (1a) is stable up to 340 °C. Interestingly, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1a does not resemble to that of 1, suggesting a structural rearrangement after desolvation. Such change is expected as the 3D framework of 1 is built up by noncovalent interactions. The activated 1a does not show any uptake for N2 at 77 K, possibly because of the contraction in the pore size after the guest removal. But at 195 K, 1a shows a stepwise uptake profile for CO2 (a). At lower pressure (until P/P 0 ≈ 0.2) uptake is low, but with increasing pressure a distinct step is realized, and finally the uptake amount reaches 57 mL/g. The desorption path creates a large hysteresis, suggesting either strong interaction of CO2 with the framework or kinetic trapping. Here, the quadrupolar CO2 can interact strongly with the aromatic π rich pore surface that induces structural rearrangement during adsorption. Also for acetylene (C2H2) low pressure uptake is low (8 mL/g), and after P/P 0 ∼ 0.1 the uptake profile rises sharply to 47 mL/g (a). The desorption curve shows a clear hysteresis, similar to the case of CO2 desorption. Here the C2H2 molecules can interact strongly with the carboxylate oxygen and aromatic π rich pore surface, and these interactions guide the structural transformation and corresponding stepwise uptake in the framework. Such stepwise uptake phenomena are commonly observed in the case of flexible framework structures.

The TG analysis of 1 showed release of the guest DMF molecules at 170 °C, and the desolvated state (1a) is stable up to 340 °C. Interestingly, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1a does not resemble to that of 1, suggesting a structural rearrangement after desolvation. Such change is expected as the 3D framework of 1 is built up by noncovalent interactions. The activated 1a does not show any uptake for N2 at 77 K, possibly because of the contraction in the pore size after the guest removal. But at 195 K, 1a shows a stepwise uptake profile for CO2 (a). At lower pressure (until P/P 0 ~ 0.2) uptake is low, but with increasing pressure a distinct step is realized, and finally the uptake amount reaches 57 mL/g. The desorption path creates a large hysteresis, suggesting either strong interaction of CO2 with the framework or kinetic trapping. Here, the quadrupolar CO2 can interact strongly with the aromatic π rich pore surface that induces structural rearrangement during adsorption. Also for acetylene (C2H2) low pressure uptake is low (8 mL/g), and after P/P 0 ~ 0.1 the uptake profile rises sharply to 47 mL/g (a). The desorption curve shows a clear hysteresis, similar to the case of CO2 desorption. Here the C2H2 molecules can interact strongly with the carboxylate oxygen and aromatic π rich pore surface, and these interactions guide the structural transformation and corresponding stepwise uptake in the framework. Such stepwise uptake phenomena are commonly observed in the case of flexible framework structures.

elements.content: (a) CO2 and C2H2 adsorption isotherms of 1a at 195 K; (b) MeOH and C6H6 vapor adsorption isotherms of 1a at 293 and 298 K; P 0 for CO2 and C2H2 are 650 and 760 Torr, respectively; P 0 for MeOH and C6H6 are 12.927 and 12.601 kPa, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) CO2 and C2H2 adsorption isotherms of 1a at 195 K; (b) MeOH and C6H6 vapor adsorption isotherms of 1a at 293 and 298 K; P 0 for CO2 and C2H2 are 650 and 760 Torr, respectively; P 0 for MeOH and C6H6 are 12.927 and 12.601 kPa, respectively.

elements.content: To obtain a better insight of the supramolecular pore structure, we have studied methanol and benzene vapor adsorption for 1a (b). Methanol vapor sorption isotherm shows a two-step uptake profile at 293 K; until P/P 0 ≈ 0.36 relative pressure a type-I profile was observed with 51 mL/g uptake, which corresponds to one methanol molecule per formula. With increasing pressure, uptake rises sharply to reach 115 mL/g (2.2 methanol molecules per formula) at P/P 0 ≈ 0.73. Another steep uptake following this pressure reaches a saturation amount of 173 mL/g, which corresponds to 3.3 molecules of methanol per formula. The desorption curve creates large hysteresis with retention of ∼1.5 molecules methanol per formula. The benzene vapor adsorption profile showed negligible uptake until P/P 0 ≈ 0.12, and then rises to reach a final uptake amount of 60 mL/g, which corresponds to ∼1.1 benzene molecules per formula (b). Here also the desorption curve creates a distinct hysteresis which might be due to strong aromatic interactions. The gate opening type profile reiterates the flexibility in the framework and also suggests a π electron-rich pore surface.
elements.clean_text: To obtain a better insight of the supramolecular pore structure, we have studied methanol and benzene vapor adsorption for 1a (b). Methanol vapor sorption isotherm shows a two-step uptake profile at 293 K; until P/P 0 ~ 0.36 relative pressure a type-I profile was observed with 51 mL/g uptake, which corresponds to one methanol molecule per formula. With increasing pressure, uptake rises sharply to reach 115 mL/g (2.2 methanol molecules per formula) at P/P 0 ~ 0.73. Another steep uptake following this pressure reaches a saturation amount of 173 mL/g, which corresponds to 3.3 molecules of methanol per formula. The desorption curve creates large hysteresis with retention of ~1.5 molecules methanol per formula. The benzene vapor adsorption profile showed negligible uptake until P/P 0 ~ 0.12, and then rises to reach a final uptake amount of 60 mL/g, which corresponds to ~1.1 benzene molecules per formula (b). Here also the desorption curve creates a distinct hysteresis which might be due to strong aromatic interactions. The gate opening type profile reiterates the flexibility in the framework and also suggests a π electron-rich pore surface.

elements.content: The absorption spectrum of 1 shows a broad feature with λmax ≈ 330 nm. Excitation of 1 at 330 nm exhibits an emission with maximum at ∼422 nm, which can be attributed to the linker ndc emission. This blue emission is red-shifted compared to that of noncoordinated ndc possibly due to metal coordination. Study of porosity, particularly the benzene adsorption profile, clearly indicates that the pore surface favors diffusion of aromatic molecules. Moreover, the framework is dynamic (flexible) and also exhibits blue emission. All of these features together encouraged us to carry out a dye loading experiment in 1a. We selected fluorescein (fl) dye, whose molecular size matches well with the pore size of 1 and its absorbance spectrum overlaps partially with the framework emission. Only 0.04 molecule of fl dye was encapsulated into the framework 1a (1a@fl), and inclusion was confirmed from 1H NMR, CO2, and solvent vapor adsorption studies. Inclusion compound 1a@fl shows only ∼20 mL/g uptake of CO2 (one-third of the amount in 1a), which suggests a decrease of the void space due to dye inclusion (a). In the case of methanol vapor adsorption, the step observed at P/P 0 ≈ 0.36 in 1a is absent in 1a@fl, and the total uptake amount decreased to 94 mL/g (1.9 methanol per formula), i.e., nearly half of the amount in 1a (b). Similarly, the benzene vapor uptake also decreased to half of the amount in 1a (∼0.6 molecules per formula). The substantial amount of decrease in uptake capacity, and change in the nature of adsorption profile, confirm inclusion of dye molecules inside the pores, and also indicate availability of void space for additional guest solvent inclusion.

This blue emission is red-shifted compared to that of noncoordinated ndc possibly due to metal coordination. Study of porosity, particularly the benzene adsorption profile, clearly indicates that the pore surface favors diffusion of aromatic molecules. Moreover, the framework is dynamic (flexible) and also exhibits blue emission. All of these features together encouraged us to carry out a dye loading experiment in 1a. We selected fluorescein (fl) dye, whose molecular size matches well with the pore size of 1 and its absorbance spectrum overlaps partially with the framework emission. Only 0.04 molecule of fl dye was encapsulated into the framework 1a (1a@fl), and inclusion was confirmed from 1H NMR, CO2, and solvent vapor adsorption studies. Inclusion compound 1a@fl shows only ~20 mL/g uptake of CO2 (one-third of the amount in 1a), which suggests a decrease of the void space due to dye inclusion (a). In the case of methanol vapor adsorption, the step observed at P/P 0 ~ 0.36 in 1a is absent in 1a@fl, and the total uptake amount decreased to 94 mL/g (1.9 methanol per formula), i.e., nearly half of the amount in 1a (b). elements.content: (a) CO2 adsorption isotherm of 1a@fl at 195 K; (b) MeOH and C6H6 vapor adsorption isotherms of 1a@fl at 293 and 298 K; respective P 0 values are as in Figure .
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) CO2 adsorption isotherm of 1a@fl at 195 K; (b) MeOH and C6H6 vapor adsorption isotherms of 1a@fl at 293 and 298 K; respective P 0 values are as in Figure  .

elements.content: The absorption spectrum of 1a@fl exhibits a new peak at ∼500 nm, attributed to the encapsulated fluorescein dye, along with framework absorbance at 330 nm. Excitation of 1a@fl at 330 nm shows two distinct emission bands with maxima at ∼432 and 535 nm, which are attributed to the framework and encapsulated dye, respectively (a). Such dual emission leads to yellow-green emission in 1a@fl (inset a). Direct excitation of 1a@fl at 490 nm shows comparatively low intensity emission at 535 nm, which suggests energy transfer from donor framework to the fl dye (a). Excitation spectrum of 1a@fl monitored at 550 nm reiterates the energy transfer process. Further, the fluorescence lifetime of framework in 1a@fl (∼1.9 ns) decreases significantly compared to 1 (∼2.8 ns) when monitored at 400 nm. On the other hand, monitoring the fluorescence lifetime of the encapsulated dye (∼4.8 ns) at 550 nm shows a subtle increase compared to that in free fluorescein (∼4.1 ns). This also advocates the presence of the energy transfer process. However, the presence of donor (host framework) emission with a decay time of ∼1.9 ns suggests a partial energy transfer from the framework to the fl dye.
elements.clean_text: The absorption spectrum of 1a@fl exhibits a new peak at ~500 nm, attributed to the encapsulated fluorescein dye, along with framework absorbance at 330 nm. Excitation of 1a@fl at 330 nm shows two distinct emission bands with maxima at ~432 and 535 nm, which are attributed to the framework and encapsulated dye, respectively (a). Such dual emission leads to yellow-green emission in 1a@fl (inset a). Direct excitation of 1a@fl at 490 nm shows comparatively low intensity emission at 535 nm, which suggests energy transfer from donor framework to the fl dye (a). Excitation spectrum of 1a@fl monitored at 550 nm reiterates the energy transfer process. Further, the fluorescence lifetime of framework in 1a@fl (~1.9 ns) decreases significantly compared to 1 (~2.8 ns) when monitored at 400 nm. On the other hand, monitoring the fluorescence lifetime of the encapsulated dye (~4.8 ns) at 550 nm shows a subtle increase compared to that in free fluorescein (~4.1 ns). This also advocates the presence of the energy transfer process. However, the presence of donor (host framework) emission with a decay time of ~1.9 ns suggests a partial energy transfer from the framework to the fl dye.

elements.content: (a) Emission spectra of 1a@fl upon excitation at 330 and 490 nm. Inset: picture of 1a@fl under UV light; (b) emission spectra of 1a@fl dispersed in different solvents upon excitation at 330 nm; (c) photographs of 1a@fl dispersed in different solvents and upon continuous solvent vapor exposure; (d) plot of emission intensity ratios I 435/I 535 observed in different solvents.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Emission spectra of 1a@fl upon excitation at 330 and 490 nm. Inset: picture of 1a@fl under UV light; (b) emission spectra of 1a@fl dispersed in different solvents upon excitation at 330 nm; (c) photographs of 1a@fl dispersed in different solvents and upon continuous solvent vapor exposure; (d) plot of emission intensity ratios I 435/I 535 observed in different solvents.

elements.content: The dual emissive 1a@fl was exploited as a probe material for various solvents. Initially, 1a@fl was dispersed in solvents such as methanol, acetonitrile, DMF, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and benzene. Their emission spectra featured distinct I 435/I 535 ratios, i.e., different emission colors (b–c). The I 435/I 535 ratios are 0.71 (DMF), 0.53 (methanol), 2.37 (benzene), 0.83 (DMSO), and 0.98 (acetonitrile) (d). Such changes in emission colors in the presence of different solvents of different polarity are unique in supramolecular framework systems, and the dye encapsulated compound 1a@fl can be used as a fingerprint sensing material. Diffusion of the solvents into the porous matrix can be confirmed from the methanol and benzene vapor adsorption profiles as described before. Hence, the spectral change is possibly induced by the structural change upon solvent vapor diffusion. As the structure is flexible, solvents might rearrange the structure, and this leads to different arrangement of fluorescein dye inside the supramolecular pores of 1a. To confirm the structural change, 1a@fl was dipped into the respective solvents (minimum amount), and PXRD patterns were collected in wet condition. PXRD patterns clearly suggest a structural change upon solvent diffusion into the supramolecular pores, and thus the energy transfer and emission properties are tuned.
elements.clean_text: The dual emissive 1a@fl was exploited as a probe material for various solvents. Initially, 1a@fl was dispersed in solvents such as methanol, acetonitrile, DMF, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and benzene. Their emission spectra featured distinct I 435/I 535 ratios, i.e., different emission colors (b-c). The I 435/I 535 ratios are 0.71 (DMF), 0.53 (methanol), 2.37 (benzene), 0.83 (DMSO), and 0.98 (acetonitrile) (d). Such changes in emission colors in the presence of different solvents of different polarity are unique in supramolecular framework systems, and the dye encapsulated compound 1a@fl can be used as a fingerprint sensing material. Diffusion of the solvents into the porous matrix can be confirmed from the methanol and benzene vapor adsorption profiles as described before. Hence, the spectral change is possibly induced by the structural change upon solvent vapor diffusion. As the structure is flexible, solvents might rearrange the structure, and this leads to different arrangement of fluorescein dye inside the supramolecular pores of 1a. To confirm the structural change, 1a@fl was dipped into the respective solvents (minimum amount), and PXRD patterns were collected in wet condition. PXRD patterns clearly suggest a structural change upon solvent diffusion into the supramolecular pores, and thus the energy transfer and emission properties are tuned.

elements.content: In conclusion, a 3D supramolecular porous framework (1) from noncovalent organization of a 1D coordination polymer has been synthesized. It possesses large 1D channels which contract after guest solvent removal. The dynamic nature of the framework was realized from CO2, C2H2, and solvent vapor adsorption studies. Benzene vapor adsorption indicates ab aromatic π electron-rich pore surface, and hence fluorescein dye could be encapsulated inside the supramolecular pores. The dye encapsulated framework shows dual emission characteristics with yellow-green emission. Moreover, a partial energy transfer phenomenon was observed from the host framework to the guest dye. Interestingly, 1a@fl shows characteristic emission when dispersed or exposed to different solvents and respective vapors such as methanol, acetonitrile, DMF, DMSO, and benzene, leading to easy detection of each solvent. Solvent induced structural change is the most plausible factor that tunes the dual emission intensity ratios. Such type of recognition path will lead to a more efficient sensing process and also novel sensory materials.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a 3D supramolecular porous framework (1) from noncovalent organization of a 1D coordination polymer has been synthesized. It possesses large 1D channels which contract after guest solvent removal. The dynamic nature of the framework was realized from CO2, C2H2, and solvent vapor adsorption studies. Benzene vapor adsorption indicates ab aromatic π electron-rich pore surface, and hence fluorescein dye could be encapsulated inside the supramolecular pores. The dye encapsulated framework shows dual emission characteristics with yellow-green emission. Moreover, a partial energy transfer phenomenon was observed from the host framework to the guest dye. Interestingly, 1a@fl shows characteristic emission when dispersed or exposed to different solvents and respective vapors such as methanol, acetonitrile, DMF, DMSO, and benzene, leading to easy detection of each solvent. Solvent induced structural change is the most plausible factor that tunes the dual emission intensity ratios. Such type of recognition path will lead to a more efficient sensing process and also novel sensory materials.

cln_elements.content:
To assess the potential of 1 as a suitable host, we have examined its porosity and structural flexibility. The TG analysis of 1 showed release of the guest DMF molecules at 170 °C, and the desolvated state (1a) is stable up to 340 °C. Interestingly, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1a does not resemble to that of 1, suggesting a structural rearrangement after desolvation. Such change is expected as the 3D framework of 1 is built up by noncovalent interactions. The activated 1a does not show any uptake for N2 at 77 K, possibly because of the contraction in the pore size after the guest removal. But at 195 K, 1a shows a stepwise uptake profile for CO2 (a). At lower pressure (until P/P 0 ≈ 0.2) uptake is low, but with increasing pressure a distinct step is realized, and finally the uptake amount reaches 57 mL/g. The desorption path creates a large hysteresis, suggesting either strong interaction of CO2 with the framework or kinetic trapping. Here, the quadrupolar CO2 can interact strongly with the aromatic π rich pore surface that induces structural rearrangement during adsorption. Also for acetylene (C2H2) low pressure uptake is low (8 mL/g), and after P/P 0 ∼ 0.1 the uptake profile rises sharply to 47 mL/g (a). The desorption curve shows a clear hysteresis, similar to the case of CO2 desorption. Here the C2H2 molecules can interact strongly with the carboxylate oxygen and aromatic π rich pore surface, and these interactions guide the structural transformation and corresponding stepwise uptake in the framework. Such stepwise uptake phenomena are commonly observed in the case of flexible framework structures.

To obtain a better insight of the supramolecular pore structure, we have studied methanol and benzene vapor adsorption for 1a (b). Methanol vapor sorption isotherm shows a two-step uptake profile at 293 K; until P/P 0 ≈ 0.36 relative pressure a type-I profile was observed with 51 mL/g uptake, which corresponds to one methanol molecule per formula. With increasing pressure, uptake rises sharply to reach 115 mL/g (2.2 methanol molecules per formula) at P/P 0 ≈ 0.73. Another steep uptake following this pressure reaches a saturation amount of 173 mL/g, which corresponds to 3.3 molecules of methanol per formula. The desorption curve creates large hysteresis with retention of ∼1.5 molecules methanol per formula. The benzene vapor adsorption profile showed negligible uptake until P/P 0 ≈ 0.12, and then rises to reach a final uptake amount of 60 mL/g, which corresponds to ∼1.1 benzene molecules per formula (b). Here also the desorption curve creates a distinct hysteresis which might be due to strong aromatic interactions. The gate opening type profile reiterates the flexibility in the framework and also suggests a π electron-rich pore surface.
cln_elements.clean_text:
To assess the potential of 1 as a suitable host, we have examined its porosity and structural flexibility. The TG analysis of 1 showed release of the guest DMF molecules at 170 °C, and the desolvated state (1a) is stable up to 340 °C. Interestingly, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1a does not resemble to that of 1, suggesting a structural rearrangement after desolvation. Such change is expected as the 3D framework of 1 is built up by noncovalent interactions. The activated 1a does not show any uptake for N2 at 77 K, possibly because of the contraction in the pore size after the guest removal. But at 195 K, 1a shows a stepwise uptake profile for CO2 (a). At lower pressure (until P/P 0 ~ 0.2) uptake is low, but with increasing pressure a distinct step is realized, and finally the uptake amount reaches 57 mL/g. The desorption path creates a large hysteresis, suggesting either strong interaction of CO2 with the framework or kinetic trapping. Here, the quadrupolar CO2 can interact strongly with the aromatic π rich pore surface that induces structural rearrangement during adsorption. Also for acetylene (C2H2) low pressure uptake is low (8 mL/g), and after P/P 0 ~ 0.1 the uptake profile rises sharply to 47 mL/g (a). The desorption curve shows a clear hysteresis, similar to the case of CO2 desorption. Here the C2H2 molecules can interact strongly with the carboxylate oxygen and aromatic π rich pore surface, and these interactions guide the structural transformation and corresponding stepwise uptake in the framework. Such stepwise uptake phenomena are commonly observed in the case of flexible framework structures. 

To obtain a better insight of the supramolecular pore structure, we have studied methanol and benzene vapor adsorption for 1a (b). Methanol vapor sorption isotherm shows a two-step uptake profile at 293 K; until P/P 0 ~ 0.36 relative pressure a type-I profile was observed with 51 mL/g uptake, which corresponds to one methanol molecule per formula. With increasing pressure, uptake rises sharply to reach 115 mL/g (2.2 methanol molecules per formula) at P/P 0 ~ 0.73. Another steep uptake following this pressure reaches a saturation amount of 173 mL/g, which corresponds to 3.3 molecules of methanol per formula. The desorption curve creates large hysteresis with retention of ~1.5 molecules methanol per formula. The benzene vapor adsorption profile showed negligible uptake until P/P 0 ~ 0.12, and then rises to reach a final uptake amount of 60 mL/g, which corresponds to ~1.1 benzene molecules per formula (b). Here also the desorption curve creates a distinct hysteresis which might be due to strong aromatic interactions. The gate opening type profile reiterates the flexibility in the framework and also suggests a π electron-rich pore surface.

metadata.title:
Adaptive and Guest Responsive Supramolecular Porous
Framework: Solvent Modulated
Energy Transfer toward Fingerprint Sensing
